offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: The other bhikkhu is regarded as ordained. 2) Perception: One perceives him to be innocent of the offense one is charging him with. an accusation based on the assumption or suspicion that the accused is not innocent entails no offense. 3) Intention: One wants to see him expelled from the Saṅgha. 4) Effort: One makes an unfounded charge in his presence that he is guilty of a pārājika offense
notes: Qualified to admonish: One is pure in body and verbal conduct, One is motivated by good will, One is learned in the Dhamma and Pāṭimokkhas Speak at the right time, about what is factual speak gently and what is connected with the goal. If one is unqualified then one should find another bhikkhu who is qualified to handle the charge. When accused, one should keep: truth and staying unprovoked. if an accusation can't be settled informally, it should be taken to the Community. If a bhikkhu spreads gossip about another bhikkhu, should be asked tos taken up the matter with the accused or community
formulas: , to ask permission to speak with him: "Let the venerable one give me leave. I want to speak with you — Karotu āyasmā okāsaṃ. Ahan-taṃ vattukāmo."
useful_texts: BU-SS9, 12, qualified to admonish Cv 9 5.1-2, Cv 9 5.7 and Pv 15 5.3. Bu PC12, 54,68, 71, 76 asking leave Mv 2 16.1-6, BMC2, Chapter 15

english_name: Accusation Out of Anger on an Irrelevant Pretext
rule_pali: Aññabhāgiyā: Yā pana bhikkhunī duṭṭhā dosā kupitā anattamanā aññabhāgiyaṃ adhikaraṇaṃ kiñci desaṃ lesamattaṃ upādāya bhikkhuniṃ pārājikena dhammena anuddhaṃseyya... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 9. Different Footing: Should any bhikkhunī, acting out of malice/anger, use a pretext from a different class of offense to charge a bhikkhunī with a Defeat offense... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If, thinking what is true, he reprimands him or causes him to be reprimanded, if he is out of his mind, if he is a beginner. if one makes a charge — or gets someone else to make a charge — against the accused based on what one actually perceives, there is no offense even if the issue turns out to pertain otherwise
offense_factors_bmc: 1. An Upasampadà Bhikkhu 2. Though knowing the other is not paràjika, the accuser accuses him of being paràjika 3. Accusation is unfounded with regard to the seen, heard or suspected 4. Accuses him in his presence with the intention to remove him from monkhood 5. The accused understands it instantly
notes: One has seen an action that would be an offense if committed by a bhikkhu, and one does not change the status of the evidence, but one distorts the facts of the case. Some ploys may be: "same person, different offense or same offense, different person. explanations for this rule are exactly the same as those for the preceding rule

rule_pali: Parikuppā: Yā pana bhikkhunī kupitā anattamanā evaṃ vadeyya: “Buddhaṃ paccakkhāmi, Dhammaṃ paccakkhāmi... Sikkhā paccakkhāmi... na bhabba samaṇiyo Sakyaputtiyā”... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 10. Renouncing the Training in Anger: Should any bhikkhunī, angry and displeased, say: "I renounce the Buddha... I renounce the Training... I am no longer a bhikkhunī"... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If she has not been pressed; if she stops; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: In anger: discontent, having hatred, hostile
formulas: She should be pressed like this. A competent and capable nun should inform the Sangha: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so says this in anger: “I renounce the Buddha, I renounce the Teaching, I renounce the Sangha, I renounce the training! The Sakyan daughters are not the only monastics. There are other monastics who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. I’ll practice the spiritual life with them.” And she keeps on saying it. If the Sangha is ready, it should press her to make her stop. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so says this in anger: “I renounce the Buddha, I renounce the Teaching, I renounce the Sangha, I renounce the training! The Sakyan daughters are not the only monastics. There are other monastics who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. I’ll practice the spiritual life with them.” And she keeps on saying it. The Sangha presses her to make her stop. Any nun who approves of pressing her to make her stop should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up. For the second time I speak on this matter … For the third time I speak on this matter … The Sangha has pressed nun so-and-so to stop. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

english_name: Getting Angry Over a Legal Issue
rule_pali: Dutiya-parikuppā: Yā pana bhikkhunī... evaṃ vadeyya: “Chandāgāminiyo ca bhikkhuniyo, dosāgāminiyo ca bhikkhuniyo, mohāgāminiyo ca bhikkhuniyo, bhayāgāminiyo ca bhikkhuniyo”... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 11. Accusing the Order of Partiality: Should any bhikkhunī, angry and displeased, claim that the Bhikkhunī Saṅgha follows bias, hatred, delusion, or fear... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If she has not been pressed; if she stops; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
formulas: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, because she’s angry that she has lost a legal case, says this: “The nuns are acting out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, and fear.” And she keeps on saying it. If the Sangha is ready, it should press her to make her stop. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, because she’s angry that she has lost a legal case, says this: “The nuns are acting out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, and fear.” And she keeps on saying it. The Sangha presses her to make her stop. Any nun who approves of pressing her to make her stop should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up. For the second time I speak on this matter … For the third time I speak on this matter … The Sangha has pressed nun so-and-so to stop. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Samsaṭṭhā: Dve pana bhikkhuniyo saṃsaṭṭhā viharanti pāpācārā pāpasaddā pāpasilokā aññamaññissā vajjappaṭicchādikā... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 12. Improper Association: Should bhikkhunīs live in close association, entangled with one another, engaging in bad behavior and concealing each other's faults... they commit a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If they have not been pressed; if they stop; if they are insane; if they are the first offenders
notes: Socialize: they socialize with improper bodily and verbal action. Harass the Sangha of nuns: they object on each other’s behalf when a legal procedure is being carried out against them
formulas: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nuns so-and-so and so-and-so socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. And they keep on doing it. If the Sangha is ready, it should press them to make them stop. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nuns so-and-so and so-and-so socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. And they keep on doing it. The Sangha presses them to make them stop. Any nun who approves of pressing the nuns so-and-so and so-and-so to make them stop should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up. For the second time I speak on this matter … For the third time I speak on this matter … The Sangha has pressed the nuns so-and-so and so-and-so to stop. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Dutiya-samsaṭṭhā: Tā ca bhikkhuniyo... evaṃ vadeyyuṃ: “Mā kho, ayye, tāsaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ avannā vā anavannā vā...” (Specific refusal to be admonished on association).
rule_english: 13. Admonishing on Association: Should a bhikkhunī, being admonished regarding the rule of association (above), persist in saying "Do not speak to us"... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If she has not been pressed; if she stops; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
formulas: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, after being pressed by the Sangha, says this to the nuns, “Venerables, you should socialize. Don’t live separately. There are other nuns in the Sangha who have such behavior, reputation, and notoriety, and who harass the Sangha of nuns and hide each other’s offenses. The Sangha says nothing to them. It’s because of disrespect, contempt, impatience, and slander, and because you are weak that the Sangha says to you, ‘Sisters, you socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. Be secluded, Venerables. The Sangha praises seclusion for the Sisters.’” And she keeps on saying it. If the Sangha is ready, it should press her to make her stop. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so, after being pressed by the Sangha, says this to the nuns, “Venerables, you should socialize. Don’t live separately. There are other nuns in the Sangha who have such behavior, reputation, and notoriety, and who harass the Sangha of nuns and hide each other’s offenses. The Sangha says nothing to them. It’s because of disrespect, contempt, impatience, and slander, and because you are weak that the Sangha says to you, ‘Sisters, you socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. Be secluded, Venerables. The Sangha praises seclusion for the Sisters.’” And she keeps on saying it. The Sangha presses her to make her stop. Any nun who approves of pressing her to make her stop should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up. For the second time I speak on this matter … For the third time I speak on this matter … The Sangha has pressed nun so-and-so to stop. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Saṅghabhedā: Yā pana bhikkhunī samaggassa saṅghassa bhedāya parakkameyya bhedanasaṃvattanikaṃ vā adhikaraṇaṃ samādāya paggayha tiṭṭheyya... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 14. Causing a Schism: Should any bhikkhunī persist in trying to cause a schism in a united Community... after being admonished three times... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If he has not been admonished, if he gives it up, if he is mad, out of his mind, in pain, a beginner
offense_factors_bmc: 1. Effort to make a schism 2. Being admonished in legal Vinaya kamma 3. Completion of kamma-vàca 4. He does not give up effort and attitude
notes: Schism is a serious division in the Community. 5 criteria: 1) The Community is originally united, 2) at least nine bhikkhus. 3) dispute over any of eighteen grounds for a creating a schism, 4) at least four bhikkhus on either side, 5) the two sides conduct separate Pāṭimokkha recitations, Invitation ceremonies, or other Community transactions within the same territory. Once a bhikkhu has succeeded in binding together a group the Community will have trouble achieving unanimity in rebuking him. one's aim in expounding the Dhamma and Vinaya should never be to create a faction. the bhikkhus see or hear of a bhikkhu who has begun or persists in schism, it is their duty to reprimand him three time. 1 step going to him in person, 2 take him into the midst of a formal meeting of the Community, 3 recite a formal rebuke. the Buddha advises bhikkhus to abandon controversial behavior and to yield to the mandate of the Community even if it seems unjust
useful_texts: SN45.2, AN V.129, A bilateral schism, vote from everyone to take side Mv 10, An unilateral schism, the schismatic group meets on its own, announces that it has separated from the other bhikkhus in the same territory Cv 7. Cv 7 5.3-6 . Mv 3 6-9. suspending see BMC2, Chapter 20

rule_pali: Bhedānuvattakā: Tassāyeva kho pana bhikkhuniyā bhikkhuniyo honti anuvattikā... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 15. Siding with a Schismatic: Should any bhikkhunī support a bhikkhunī who is causing a schism... after being admonished three times... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If they have not been admonished, if they give it up, if they are mad, out of their minds, in pain, beginners
offense_factors_bmc: 1. Supporting the schismatic 2. Being admonished in legal Vinaya-kamma 3. Completion of kamma-vàca 4. He does not give up effort and attitude
notes: This rule and the previos one are designed to prevent behavior in the bud before they can become schismatic. If the schismatic mentioned in the preceding rule begins to attract adherents, they are to be treated under this rule — and quickly, before the schismatic gains a fourth adherent because 1 One Community cannot impose a penalty on another Community (four or more bhikkhus) in any one transaction (Mv.IX.2). 2) Penalties of this sort may be imposed only with the unanimous agreement of all the bhikkhus present in the meeting
useful_texts: Dispute becomes major issue the procedures given in Cv 4 14.16-26, BMC 1 chapter 11. schism already occur BMC2, Chapter 21. Mv 9 2

rule_pali: Dubbacā: Yā pana bhikkhunī... dubbacajātikaṃ attānaṃ kareyya... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 16. Difficult to Admonish: Should any bhikkhunī make herself difficult to admonish ("Dubbaca"), refusing to accept valid criticism... after being admonished three times... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If he is not admonished, if he gives it up, if he is mad, if he is a beginner
offense_factors_bmc: 1. One is being unadmonishable 2. Being admonished in legal Vinaya-kamma 3. Completion of kamma-vàca 4. He does not give up effort and attitude
notes: If a bhikkhu breaks any of the rules of the Vinaya without undergoing the penalties they entail, the other bhikkhus have the duty of admonishing him. Procedure is to reprimanding him in private, admonishing and rebuking him in a formal meeting of the Community — are the same as under Sg 10. If the bhikkhu difficult to admonish carries on as before, even after incurring the full penalty under this rule, the Community may perform a banishment transaction
useful_texts: BU-PC12, 54, 71. Banishment Cv 1 .13 — see BMC2, Chapter 20

rule_pali: Kuladūsikā: Yā pana bhikkhunī gāmāssitā viharati kuladūsikā pāpasamācārā... saṅghādisesaṃ.
rule_english: 17. Corrupting Families: Should any bhikkhunī corrupt families (through flattery/gifts) and behave badly... and refuse to leave the area when banished... she commits a Saṅghādisesa offense.
no_offense_factors: If he is not admonished, if he gives it up, if he is mad, if he is a beginner
offense_factors_bmc: 1. Accusing monks as chandagàmini, dosagàmini, mohagàmini, bhayagàmini 2. Being admonished in legal Vinaya-kamma 3. Completion of kamma-vàca 4. He does not give up effort and attitude
notes: A corrupter of families is a bhikkhu who — behaving in a demeaning, frivolous, or subservient way — succeeds in ingratiating himself to lay people to the point where they withdraw their support from bhikkhus. bhikkhus can banish him
useful_texts: BMC2, Chapter 10, Cv 5 36. Banished bhikkhu duties n Cv 1 15 , Cv 1 16.1

rule_pali: Pattasannicaya: Yā pana bhikkhunī pattasannicayaṃ kareyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 1. Hoarding Bowls: Should any bhikkhunī hoard bowls (more than one), that bowl is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, before dawn, it has been determined, assigned to another, given away, lost, destroyed, broken, stolen, or taken on trust; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: A relinquished almsbowl should be given back. If a nun doesn’t give it back, she commits an offense of wrong conduct
formulas: This almsbowl, which I have kept for more than one day, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to you.’ After relinquishing it, she is to confess the offense. The confession should be received by that nun. The relinquished bowl is then to be given back: ‘I give this almsbowl back to you

rule_pali: Akālacīvara: Yā pana bhikkhunī akālacīvaraṃ kālacīvaranti adhiṭṭhaheyya bhājāpeyya vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 2. Wrong Season Robes: Should any bhikkhunī distribute robe-cloth out of season (thinking it is in season), it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she distributes out-of-season robe-cloth that she perceives as in-season; if she distributes in-season robe-cloth that she perceives as in-season; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Out-of-season robe-cloth: for one who has not participated in the robe-making ceremony, it is robe-cloth given during the eleven months. For one who has participated in the robe-making ceremony, it is robe-cloth given during the seven months. Also, if it is given in the robe season, but the cloth is designated, it is called “out-of-season robe-cloth”
formulas: It’s to be relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) … ‘Venerables, this out-of-season robe-cloth, which I distributed after determining it as “in-season”, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’

rule_pali: Cīvaraparivattana: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā saddhiṃ cīvaraṃ parivattetvā sā pacchā kupitā anattamanā acchindeyya vā acchindāpeyya vā... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 3. Exchanging Robes: Should any bhikkhunī exchange robes with another bhikkhunī and then later, angry and displeased, snatch it back or have it snatched back... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If the other nun gives it back; if she takes it on trust from her; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
formulas: It’s to be relinquished like this. Evañca pana, bhikkhave, nissajjitabbaṁ. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) …pe… … ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I took back after trading it with a nun, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … “idaṁ me, ayye, cīvaraṁ bhikkhuniyā saddhiṁ parivattetvā acchinnaṁ nissaggiyaṁ, imāhaṁ saṅghassa nissajjāmī”ti …pe… the Sangha should give … dadeyyā”ti …pe… you should give … dadeyyun”ti …pe… ‘I give this robe-cloth back to yo

rule_pali: Aññadatthika: Yā pana bhikkhunī aññadatthikena parikkhārena aññuddisikena mahājanikena saññācikena aññaṃ cetāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 4. Misusing Requisites (I): Should any bhikkhunī use a requisite (gift) asking for it for one purpose but using it for another... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she asks for both at the same time; if she can show a benefit in asking; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
formulas: It’s to be relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) … ‘Venerables, this thing, which I asked for after asking for something else, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Cīvaracchindana: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā cīvaraṃ datvā sā pacchā kupitā anattamanā acchindeyya vā acchindāpeyya vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 5. Taking Back a Gift: Should any bhikkhunī give a robe to another bhikkhunī and then, angry and displeased, snatch it back or have it snatched back... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she gets both in exchange at the same time; if she can show a benefit in doing the exchange; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
formulas: It’s to be relinquished like this. Evañca pana, bhikkhave, nissajjitabbaṁ. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) …pe… … ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange, having first gotten something else in exchange, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … “idaṁ me, ayye, aññaṁ cetāpetvā aññaṁ cetāpitaṁ nissaggiyaṁ, imāhaṁ saṅghassa nissajjāmī”ti …pe… the Sangha should give … dadeyyāti …pe… you should give … dadeyyunti …pe… ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Dutiya-aññadatthika: Yā pana bhikkhunī aññadatthikena parikkhārena aññuddisikena... aññaṃ cetāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 6. Misusing Requisites (II): Should any bhikkhunī, having asked for a requisite for a specific purpose (from a different group), use it for another purpose... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she uses the remainder; if she uses it after getting permission from the owners; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: Belonging to the Sangha, not to a group, not to an individual nun. Exchanges it for something else: if, apart from the purpose for which it was given, she exchanges it for something else, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct. When she gets it, it becomes subject to relinquishment
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Aññaviññāpana: Yā pana bhikkhunī aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpeyya... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 7. Unrelated Donors (I): Should a bhikkhunī ask for a robe from an unrelated householder... (except at the right time)... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she uses the remainder; if she uses it after getting permission from the owners; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: Belonging to the Sangha, not to a group, not to an individual nun. Exchanges it for something else: if, apart from the purpose for which it was given, she exchanges it for something else, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct. When she gets it, it becomes subject to relinquishment
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Dutiya-aññaviññāpana: Yā pana bhikkhunī aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā... cīvaraṃ viññāpeyya... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 8. Unrelated Donors (II): Should a bhikkhunī ask for a robe from an unrelated householder (who intended to give something else)... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she uses the remainder; if she uses it after getting permission from the owners; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: Collective: belonging to a group, not to the Sangha, not to an individual nun
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Tatiya-aññaviññāpana: Yā pana bhikkhunī aññātake gahapatī vā... upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjeyya... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 9. Combined Funds: Should a bhikkhunī ask for a robe from two unrelated householders who intended to combine their funds... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she uses the remainder; if she uses it after getting permission from the owners; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: Collective: belonging to a group, not to the Sangha, not to an individual nun
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Yācitaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī yācitakaṃ cīvaraṃ na paṭinissajjeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 10. Borrowed Robe: Should any bhikkhunī not return a robe she had asked for (borrowed) ... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she uses the remainder; if she uses it after getting permission from the owners; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: Personal: belonging to an individual nun, not to the Sangha, not to a group
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Garupāvuraṇa: Yā pana bhikkhunī garupāvuraṇaṃ cetāpeyya catukkaṃsaparamā, tato ce uttari cetāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 11. Heavy Cloth Price: Should any bhikkhunī obtain a heavy winter cloak for a price exceeding four 'kamsas'... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she carries out an exchange for one worth at most four kaṁsa coins; if she carries out an exchange for one worth less than four kaṁsa coins; if it is from relatives; if it is from those who have given an invitation; if it is for the benefit of someone else; if it is by means of her own property; if she gets one in exchange that has little value from someone who wants to exchange one of great value; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: A heavy cloak: whatever cloak is used in cold weather. Carries out an exchange to get: asks for
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Lahupāvuraṇa: Yā pana bhikkhunī lahupāvuraṇaṃ cetāpeyya aḍḍhateyyakaṃsaparamā, tato ce uttari cetāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 12. Light Cloth Price: Should any bhikkhunī obtain a light summer cloak for a price exceeding two and a half 'kamsas'... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she carries out an exchange for one worth at most two-and-a-half kaṁsa coins; if she carries out an exchange for one worth less than two-and-a-half kaṁsa coins; if it is from relatives; if it is from those who have given an invitation; if it is for the benefit of someone else; if it is by means of her own property; if she gets one in exchange that has little value from someone who wants to exchange one of great value; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
offense_factors_bmc: A light cloak: whatever cloak is used in warm weather. Carries out an exchange to get: asks for
formulas: Relinquished like this. (To be expanded as in Bi Np 1:2.1.21–Bi Np 1:2.1.43, with appropriate substitutions.) ‘Venerables, this thing, which I got in exchange for a requisite belonging to the Sangha that was designated for a specific purpose, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ … the Sangha should give … you should give … ‘I give this back to you

rule_pali: Suddhakāḷaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī suddhakāḷakānaṃ eḷakalomānaṃ santhataṃ kārāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 13. Pure Black Wool: Should any bhikkhunī have a rug made from pure black wool, it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, within ten days, it is allotted, assigned, bestowed, lost, destroyed, burnt, if they tear it from him, if they take it on trust; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a piece of extra robe-cloth, suitable to be made into a robe or other cloth requisite, measuring at least four by eight inches (fingerbreadths), that has not been formally determined for use or placed under shared ownership. This category includes finished requisites as well as simple pieces of cloth, but does not include robe-cloth belonging to the Community. 2) Effort: One keeps it for more than ten days (except during the allowed period) without determining it for use, placing it under shared ownership, abandoning it (giving or throwing it away); and without the cloth's being lost, destroyed, burnt, snatched away, or taken by someone else on trust within that time
notes: The spirit of the rule makes it incumbent on each bhikkhu to keep his cloth requisites to a minimum. Mv 8 21.1 states that if a bhikkhu receives a piece of suitable cloth but does not yet plan to use it, he may place it under shared ownership (vikappana) until he has need for it. Counts as extra cloth if — it has not been or improperly determined for use or placed under shared ownership, or its determination or shared ownership has lapsed. shared ownership lapse if first owner takes the cloth on trust, or the second owner formally rescinds the shared ownership. To use an unforfeited item that deserves to be forfeited incurs a dukkaṭa. Robe season from first full moon in October and lasting 1 month Bu NP 1 & 3; Pc 32, 33, & 46 — are relaxed. Participating in Kaṭhina ceremony these privileges exend until full-moon day that ends the cold season in late February or early-to-mid March. bhikkhu who does not return the article being forfeited incurs a dukkaṭa
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante cīvaraṁ dasāhātikkantaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi. This means, “This robe (robe-cloth) of mine, venerable sir, kept beyond ten days, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.” plural: Imāni me bhante cīvarāni dasāhātikkantāni nissaggiyāni. Imānāhaṃ āyasmato nissajjāmi
useful_texts: AN8.53, Mv 8 13.4-8, unsuitable materials, see Mv 8 28 — BMC2, Chapter 2. shared ownership BU-PC59. Kaṭhina privilages resinded Mv7 1.7; Mv 7 2 & Pv14 6

rule_pali: Dvebhāga: Yā pana bhikkhunī navaṃ santhataṃ kārāpayamānā... dve bhāge suddhakāḷakānaṃ eḷakalomānaṃ... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 14. Two Parts Black: Should any bhikkhunī have a rug made without taking two parts white wool... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If before sunrise it is taken away, bestowed, lost, destroyed, burnt; if they tear it from him; if they take it on trust; if there is the agreement of the monks, if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer. when the kaṭhina privileges are in effect
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: any one of the robes that a bhikkhu has determined as his basic set of three. This rule thus does not apply to spare robes or other cloth requisites. 2 Effort: greeting dawnrise at a place outside of the zone in which any of one's robes are located, except when the exemptions mentioned in the rule are in effect
notes: Commentary's position is that in cases where the Vibhaṅga says that if the robes are kept in a certain area, one should either stay in that area or not more than a hatthapāsa away from the outside boundary of the area. If he thinks that he is in the same zone when he actually isn't, if he thinks the robe is not determined when it actually is, or if he means to be in the same zone when circumstances prevent him, he incurs the penalty all the same
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante cīvaraṁ ratti-vippavutthaṁ aññatra bhikkhu-sammatiyā nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This robe of mine, venerable sir, from which I dwelled apart for a night without authorization of the bhikkhus, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”

rule_pali: Chabbassa: Yā pana bhikkhunī navaṃ santhataṃ kārāpetvā chabbassāni dhāretabbaṃ... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 15. Six Years: Should any bhikkhunī have a rug made (and not keep it for six years)... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If within a month it is allotted, assigned, bestowed, lost, destroyed, burnt, if they tear it from him, if they take it on trust; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: (a) out-of-season robe-cloth, made of any of the proper six kinds of material, in pieces measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths; (b) the cloth is not enough to make the cloth requisite one has in mind, but one expects to receive more. 2) Effort: One keeps the cloth for more than 30 days, except when the kaṭhina privileges are in effect
notes: Cloth accruing to a bhikkhu during the one-month or five-month robe season can count as out-of-season cloth if the donors dedicate it to that purpose, in order to extend the period it can be kept or visiting bhikkhus. If the second cloth turns out to be of different quality from the first, one is under no compulsion to put the two cloths together to make up the requisite if one does not want to. out-of-season cloth received shortly before the beginning of the robe season, the countdown would begin when it is received, would be suspended throughout the robe season, and would resume at the robe season's end
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante akāla-cīvaraṁ māsātikkantaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This out-of-season robe-cloth of mine, venerable sir, kept beyond a month, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”
useful_texts: Bu Np 1, 24. Mv.V.13.13 the counting of the time span does not begin until the cloth has reached one's hand

rule_pali: Nisīdanasanthata: Yā pana bhikkhunī nisīdanasanthataṃ kārāpayamānā purāṇasanthatassa sāmantā sugatavidatthi āḍātabbā... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 16. Sitting Rug: Should any bhikkhunī have a new sitting rug made without taking a piece of the old one... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it is at the right time; if they belong to relations; if they are invited; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a piece of any of the six suitable kinds of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths. 2) Effort: One asks, except at the proper time, for such cloth from a lay person who is not related back through one's great x 7 grandfathers. Even if one perceives the lay person to be related when in fact he/she isn't, that fulfills the factor here. 3) Result: One receives the cloth
notes: If all of a bhikkhu's robes are snatched away or destroyed, should not approach other people while naked. he is permitted to take any cloth he finds there — robes, sheets, mats, pillow cases, or whatever — to wear as a makeshift robe as long as he has the intention of returning it when he obtains a proper robe
formulas: Idaṃ me bhante cīvaraṃ aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ aññatra samayā viññāpitaṃ nissaggiyaṃ. Imāhaṃ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, "This robe (robe-cloth) of mine, venerable sir, requested from an unrelated householder at other than the proper occasion, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you." For more than one robe: Imāni me bhante cīvarāni aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ aññatra samayā viññāpitāni nissaggiyāni. Imānāhaṃ āyasmato nissajjāmi

rule_pali: Eḷakaloma: Yā pana bhikkhunī eḷakalomāni paṭiggaṇheyya... tihanayojanaṃ sahatthā haritabbaṃ... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 17. Carrying Wool: Should any bhikkhunī carry wool for more than three leagues... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: One takes excess cloth with the promise to return the excess when one has finished one's robe(s), and the donors tell one to keep the excess the donors are offering cloth for reasons other than that one's robes were snatched away or destroyed one is asking from one's relatives or people who have previously made one an invitation to ask for cloth or one gets the cloth by means of one's own resources
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: any piece of the six kinds of suitable robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths. 2) Effort: One asks for more than the allowable amount of robe-cloth from an unrelated householder who has not previously made an invitation to ask. 3) Result: One gets the excess robe-cloth
notes: The allowance in the preceding rule applies only when robes from one's basic set of three, If one's spare robes get snatched away or destroyed, one may not make use of the allowance to ask for robe-cloth at all. one should take only enough cloth to make the allowable number of robes. one may take excess cloth if one promises to return the excess when one has finished making one's robe(s). And if the donor tells one to keep the excess, one may do so without penalty
formulas: Idaṃ me bhante cīvaraṃ aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ tad'uttariṃ viññāpitaṃ nissaggiyaṃ. Imāhaṃ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, "This robe (robe-cloth) of mine, venerable sir, requested beyond that (allowable) from an unrelated householder, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you." For more than one robe: Imāni me bhante cīvarāni aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ tad'uttariṃ viññāpitāni nissaggiyāni. Imānāhaṃ āyasmato nissajjāmi

english_name: Robes Fine Request From Robe Fund
rule_pali: Jātarūparajata: Yā pana bhikkhunī jātarūparajataṃ uggaṇheyya vā uggaṇhāpeyya vā... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 18. Gold and Silver: Should any bhikkhunī accept gold or silver (money), or get someone else to accept it... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If they belong to relations, if they are invited; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; if he gets something of small value in exchange while he desires to get something costly in exchange; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object. The texts mention only that this rule concerns funds for a robe (cīvara) would probably mean a finished robe. 2 Intention. One wants to get a better robe than the lay person is planning to buy. "better quality, higher price." 3 Effort. One requests the unrelated lay person to improve the robe. 4 Result. One gets the long, broad, etc., robe that the householder bought in line with one's request
notes: A wise policy for a bhikkhu not to make stipulations, when uninvited, to a lay person who has prepared funds for purchasing any kind of requisite for his use
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante cīvaraṁ pubbe appavārito aññātakaṁ gahapatikaṁ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṁ āpannaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This cloth, venerable sir—mine after, without having been invited beforehand, I approached an unrelated householder and made stipulations about cloth—is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”

english_name: Robes Fine Request From Combined Robe Fund
rule_pali: Rūpiyasaṃvohāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī nānappakārakaṃ rūpiyasaṃvohāraṃ samāpajjeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 19. Monetary Exchange: Should any bhikkhunī engage in various types of monetary exchange, it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If they belong to relations, if they are invited; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; if he gets something of small value in exchange while he desires to get something costly in exchange; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object. The texts mention only that this rule concerns funds for a robe (cīvara) would probably mean a finished robe. 2 Intention. One wants to get a better robe than the lay person is planning to buy. "better quality, higher price." 3 Effort. One asks the two donors to put their funds together to purchase one robe.. 4 Result. One gets the long, broad, etc., robe that the householder bought in line with one's request
notes: The question of whether the request would raise the amount of money they would have to spend is not an issue here, although the Vibhaṅga says that if one makes a request that would reduce the amount of money they would spend, there is no offense
formulas: For cloth received after making stipulations to two or more unrelated householders, use the same formula as for the preceding rule, changing aññātakaṁ gahapatikaṁ to aññātake gahapatike

rule_pali: Kayavikkay: Yā pana bhikkhunī nānappakārakaṃ kayavikkayam samāpajjeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 20. Buying and Selling: Should any bhikkhunī engage in various types of buying and selling, it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: In stating three times, in standing six times; in stating less than three times, in standing less than six times; if himself not stating, he gives; if stating, the owners give; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a fund for the purchase of robe-cloth left with a steward. This factor to cover any fund set aside for one's own requisites. 2) Effort: One makes an excessive number of promptings. A dukkaṭa for the excessive promptings 3) Result: One obtains the requested requisite
notes: The purpose of the protocols is to free bhikkhus from the even more bothersome worries and complexities that come with participating in buying, selling, and monetary matters in general. If a bhikkhu follows the protocols recommended here, the money placed with the steward still belongs to the donor, and the responsibility for making a fair trade lies with the steward. Important that he not abuse the steward's services. One may say only, "I need a robe (or whatever the requisite may be), Not "Give me a robe," "Get me a robe," "Buy me a robe. To apply the protocols where the steward is indicated by the bhikkhu, by the donor, or by neither . For Sangha an acceptable phrased "This is for the purpose of the four requisites," or "Accept whatever is allowable coming from this," without mentioning the Saṅgha or any bhikkhu. But not "I'm giving this to the Saṅgha," for whatever the purpose, the gift may not be accepted. For donation boxes "The donation box is over there," but not, "Put it there." If checking account is set up for impersonal purposes such as the construction and upkeep of monastery buildings, a bhikkhu may not sign a check drawing on the account. A fund has been set up for a particular requisite, it should as a general principle be used to buy only that requisite
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante cīvaraṁ atireka-tikkhattuṁ codanāya atireka-chakkhattuṁ ṭhānena abhinipphāditaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This robe (robe-cloth) of mine, venerable sir, produced after more than three reminders, after more than six standings, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”
useful_texts: AN4.28, Bu NP 18, 19, & 20. BU-PC84. Mv 6 34.21 Meṇḍaka Allowance

rule_pali: Pattachidda: Yā pana bhikkhunī atirekapattaṃ dhāreyya, dasāhaparamaṃ nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 21. Extra Bowl: Should any bhikkhunī keep an extra bowl for more than ten days, it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: Finding gold or money lying around the monastery or in a house he is visiting, puts it away in safe keeping for the owner
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: gold or silver intended for one.. Or whatever is used as a currency = (1) They are a generally accepted medium of exchange; (2) they are of standard recognized value; and (3) they are presentable by any bearer 2) Effort: One accepts, having it accepted, or consenting to its being deposited
notes: By accepting money,one is accepting all the cares, responsibilities, and dangers that come with its ownership. Relinquish to Sangha and not to be returned or benefit the offender, but used by Sangha through lay follower or thrown away by a selected bhikkhu . Whether the bhikkhu accepts gold or money for himself or for others is thus not an issue here. Anything that falls short of a command, though, would not fulfill this factor. It can be refuse either in thought, word, or deed. if the donor does not mention the name of the bhikkhu or the Community as custodians or recipients of the funds, the donations are not to be refused. Rather, they are to be left there and the steward told of what the donor said
formulas: Ahaṁ bhante rūpiyaṁ paṭiggahesiṁ. Idaṁ me nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ saṅghassa nissajjāmi. This means, “Venerable sirs, I have received money. This of mine is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to the Community.”

rule_pali: Ūnapañcabandhana: Yā pana bhikkhunī ūnapañcabandhanena pattena aññaṃ navaṃ pattaṃ cetāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 22. New Bowl: Should any bhikkhunī ask for a new bowl when her old one is mended in less than five places... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object, money is any type of items used as currency. 2) Effort here includes any exchange in which the bhikkhu ends up with gold or money as a result of the exchange
notes: By arranging a trade, one is accepting responsibility for the fairness of the trade. Relinquish to Sangha and not to be returned or benefit the offender, but used by Sangha through lay follower or thrown away by a selected bhikkhu. bhikkhu may not express a desire to his steward that he/she sell something belonging to him or take funds dedicated for his use and invest them for monetary return. Money obtained improperly, the object bought with the money is unallowable for all bhikkhus. But if obtained obtained properly under the preceding rule, the item bought is unallowable only for the bhikkhu buyer, and allowed to the rest
formulas: Ahaṁ bhante nānappakārakaṁ rūpiya-saṁvohāraṁ samāpajjiṁ. Idaṁ me nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ saṅghassa nissajjāmi. This means, “Venerable sirs, I have engaged in various types of monetary exchange. This of mine is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to the Community.”

rule_pali: Bhesajjapaṭisevana: Yāni kho pana tāni gilānānaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ paṭisāyanīyāni bhesajjāni... sattāhaparamaṃ sannidhikārakaṃ paribhuñjitabbāni... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 23. Storing Medicine: Should any bhikkhunī store tonics (ghee, oil, honey, molasses) for more than seven days... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he asks the price of an object; if he tells a steward; if he tells the seller, “I have this. I have need of such-and-such", and then lets the seller arrange the exchange as he/she sees fit. if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object. All types of trade not covered in previous rule. 2 Effort. Engaging in trade by proposing and ones goods ending up with the other person, and the other person’s goods ending up with the bhikkhu
notes: Any transaction in which the end product is other than gold or money, i.e. buying as well as bartering the forfeited article should be returned to the original offender not to return the article would be a dukkata. No exemptions for a bhikkhu who trades using goods belonging to someone else. The Vibhaṅga makes no mention of what the bhikkhu may and may not do with the article after receiving it in return, but commentary have protocols. Present rule thus covers trades made only with not one’s co-religionists. bhikkhus should not bargain, if he sees that the steward is getting a bad deal, he may simply tell the steward, “Don’t take it Checks, credit cards, debit cards, and traveler’s checks do not count as gold or money. However, any trade arranged with them would come under this rule
formulas: Ahaṁ bhante nānappakārakaṁ kaya-vikkayaṁ samāpajjiṁ. Idaṁ me nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “Venerable sir, I have engaged in various types of trade. This of mine is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.” To return the article: Imaṁ āyasmato dammi, which means, “I give this to you.”
useful_texts: SN42.10, AN4.50, Bu Np 5 10, 18, 19, 20 BU-PC84, Misuse donations Mv 8 22.1; BMC2, Chapter 10

rule_pali: Vassikasāṭika: Yā pana bhikkhunī... vassikasāṭikaṃ pariyesitabbā... tato ce uttari... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 24. Rains Bathing Cloth: Should any bhikkhunī have a rains bathing cloth made (outside the allowed time)... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If the bowl is destroyed, if the bowl is broken, if they belong to relations, if they are invited, if it is for another, if it is by means of his own property; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: Before one’s alms bowl is beyond repair, one asks for 2) Object: a new almsbowl fit to be determined for use. 3) Result: One obtains the bowl
notes: Relinquish to Sangha according to procedure. this rule allows a bhikkhu whose bowl is beyond repair to ask for a new one. Community chooses one of its members as bowl exchanger. If the new bowl is preferable to one's own and yet one do not take it out of sympathy for the offender, is a dukkaṭa, but for contentment with what he has, no offense
formulas: Ayaṁ me bhante patto ūna-pañca-bandhanena pattena cetāpito nissaggiyo. Imāhaṁ saṅghassa nissajjāmi. This means, “This bowl of mine, venerable sirs, asked for when the (previous) bowl had less than five mends, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to the Community.”
useful_texts: BU-PC21, wrong use of bowl BMC2, Chapter 3

rule_pali: Cīvara-acchindana: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā cīvaraṃ datvā... acchindeyya... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 25. Snatching Robe (Anger): Should any bhikkhunī, having given a robe to another, snatch it back in anger... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If within seven days the tonic gets lost, destroyed, burnt, snatched away, or taken on trust; or if the bhikkhu determines it for use, abandons it, or—having given it away to an unordained person, abandoning desire for it—he receives it in return and makes use of it if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: any of the five tonics. 2) Effort: One keeps the tonic past the seventh dawnrise after receiving it
notes: Acquiring something that has been forfeited,it must not be made use of for bodily enjoyment nor consumed. any tonic received today may be eaten mixed with food or juice drinks received today, but not with food or juice drinks received on a later day. one may take the tonic at any time during those seven days regardless of whether one is ill
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante bhesajjaṁ sattāhātikkantaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This medicine of mine, venerable sir, kept beyond seven days, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to

rule_pali: Suttaviññāpana: Yā pana bhikkhunī attanā viññāpetvā suttaṃ tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 26. Asking for Yarn: Should any bhikkhunī ask for yarn and have a robe woven by weavers... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he gives it or takes (from him) in a friendly manner; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: A piece of any of the six allowable kinds of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths. 2 Effort: One has given the cloth to another bhikkhu on one condition or another and then either snatches it back or has someone else snatch it back. 3 Intention: One is impelled by anger or displeasure
notes: This rule is for cases where one perceives the robe-cloth as being rightfully one’s own even after having given it away. But when not out of anger or annoyance, but ‘with the mind of a thief’ (theyya-citta) then is Pj 2. dukkaṭa for angrily snatching back from a bhikkhu requisites other than cloth; and for angrily snatching back any kind of requisite—cloth or otherwise—that one has given to someone who is not a bhikkhu
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante cīvaraṁ bhikkhussa sāmaṁ datvā acchinnaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This robe (robe-cloth) of mine, venerable sir, snatched back after I myself gave it to a bhikkhu, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”

rule_pali: Mahāpesakāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī... tantavāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 27. Instructing Weavers: Should any bhikkhunī instruct a weaver (paid by someone else) to make the robe better/wider/longer... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: Is no offence to sew a robe to a binding, to a belt, to a shoulder-strap, to a bag for carrying the bowl in, to a water-strainer; if it belongs to relations; if they are invited; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Thread or yarn of the six allowable types for robe-cloth that a bhikkhu has himself requested from others. 2 Effort: One gets weavers to weave robe-cloth using the thread. 3 Result: One obtains the cloth
notes: This rule covers two actions—asking for thread and getting weavers to weave it into robe-cloth
useful_texts: Bu Np 11-15 and Pc 86-92: no offense for the request itself, but a dukkaṭa if the request successfully persuades the other person to act in line with it

rule_pali: Accekacīvara: Dasāhānāgataṃ kattikatemāsipuṇṇamaṃ... accekacīvaraṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 28. Urgent Robe: Should any bhikkhunī accept an urgent robe (before the Rains) and keep it beyond the allowed time... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it belongs to relations; if they are invited; if it is for another; if it is by means of his own property; if desirous of having costly (robe-material) woven he has (robe-material) costing little woven; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: A piece of any of the six allowable types of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths, which is being made for one’s sake by the arrangement of a donor who is unrelated and has not given an invitation to ask. 2 Effort: One approaches the weavers and gets them to improve the cloth in any of the seven ways mentioned in the rule. 3 Result: One obtains the cloth
notes: Whether or not a gift is offered to the weaver, the offences under this rule are still the same. (Some have objected that it should be all right for the bhikkhu to pay in full for the improvements in the robe, but remember that to do so would be an insult to the donors.)

rule_pali: Sāsaṅka: Yā pana bhikkhunī... tīcīvarena vippavaseyya chārattaṃ paramaṃ... nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 29. Wilderness Separation: Should any bhikkhunī stay apart from her robes in a dangerous wilderness for more than six nights... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, within the season, it is allotted, assigned, bestowed, lost, destroyed, burnt, if they tear it (from him), if they take it on trust; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Robe-cloth offered in urgency is any piece of the six allowable kinds of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths. The does not want to wait until the robe season to make an offering. 2 effort—one keeps it past the end of the robe season
notes: The third-month Kattika full moon is the first full moon in October. This is the final day of the first Rains-residence, and the day before the beginning of the robe season. donor offers robe-material to a particular monk before the end of the Rains-Retreat, then it may be accepted by him, but in no circumstances does this count as an acceka-cīvara. An acceka-cīvara ia a Rains-Retreat gift given to the Sangha at a monastery within ten days of the end of the Rains-Retreat
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante acceka-cīvaraṁ cīvara-kāla-samayaṁ atikkāmitaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This robe-cloth-offered-in-urgency of mine, venerable sir, kept beyond the robe season, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”

rule_pali: Pariṇata: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ saṅghikaṃ lābhaṃ pariṇataṃ attano pariṇāmeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 30. Diverting Gains: Should any bhikkhunī knowingly divert gain (intended for the Community) to herself... it is to be forfeited and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he himself being asked, ‘Where do we give?’ says, ‘Give wherever your gift would be used or could be mended or should be for a long time or when for you the mind is inspired; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Any requisite “robe-cloth, almsfood, lodgings, medicine, even a lump of powder, tooth wood, or unwoven thread”—that donors have indicated by word or gesture that they intend to give to a Community. 2 Perception. that the donors have allocated the requisite for a Community. 3 Effort. One tries to persuade them that they should give it to oneself instead. (The texts make no allowance for kappiya-vohāra here.) 4 Result. One obtains the article from the donors
notes: Would then seem appropriate, although this is not stated in the Vinaya, that the offending monk should then present that gift to the Sangha where it was originally intended. the point of this rule that monks have no business telling donors where to give their gifts. any donor lay, fellow bhikkhus and relatives. The fact that a gift is allocated for a Community overrides all other considerations, even when one is ill. perceiving an item as not allocated does not give carte blanche to divert it as one likes
formulas: Idaṁ me bhante jānaṁ saṅghikaṁ lābhaṁ pariṇataṁ attano pariṇāmitaṁ nissaggiyaṁ. Imāhaṁ āyasmato nissajjāmi, which means, “This of mine, venerable sir, which—knowing it was intended for the Community—I diverted for myself, is to be forfeited. I forfeit it to you.”

rule_pali: Lasuṇa: Yā pana bhikkhunī lasuṇaṃ khādeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 1. Garlic: Should any bhikkhunī eat garlic, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it is an onion; if it is a shallot; if it is chebulic myrobalan; if it is a spring onion; if it is cooked in a bean curry; if it is cooked with meat; if it is cooked with oil; if it is in sweets; if it is a special curry; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Sambādhaloma: Yā pana bhikkhunī sambādhalomaṃ saṃhareyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 2. Removing Hair: Should any bhikkhunī remove hair from a sensitive area (armpits/pubis)... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Talaghātaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī talaghātakaṃ dadeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 3. Slapping: Should any bhikkhunī slap herself with her palms... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Jatumaṭṭhaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī jatumaṭṭhake āmasanaṃ vā parāmasanaṃ vā... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 4. Wax Paddle: Should any bhikkhunī use a lac-paddle (dildo) for sexual stimulation... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Udakasuddhika: Yā pana bhikkhunī udakasuddhikaṃ ādiyeyya... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 5. Washing (Water): Should any bhikkhunī wash deep inside her vagina... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she inserts two finger joints; if she inserts less than two finger joints; if she does it because she is sick; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: I allow the nuns to clean themselves with water Is cleaning herself with water: rinsing the vagina is what is meant

rule_pali: Upatiṭṭhana: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuṃ bhuñjantaṃ pānīyena vā vidhūpanena vā upatiṭṭheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 6. Hosting (Food): Should any bhikkhunī stand and serve water/fans to a monk while he is eating... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she gives something; if she has someone else give something; if she asks someone who is not fully ordained to do it; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Āmakadhañña: Yā pana bhikkhunī āmakadhaññaṃ viññāpetvā vā viññāpāpetvā vā bhajjitvā vā bhajjāpetvā vā koṭṭetvā vā koṭṭāpetvā vā pacitvā vā pacāpetvā vā khādeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 7. Raw Grain: Should any bhikkhunī ask for and eat raw grain... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she does it because she is sick; if she asks for vegetables; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences. If she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct

rule_pali: Uccāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā saṅkāraṃ vā vighāsaṃ vā tirokuṭṭe vā tiropākāre vā chaḍḍeyya vā chaḍḍāpeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 8. Throwing Waste (Wall): Should any bhikkhunī throw feces/urine/trash over a wall or fence... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she disposes of it after having looked; if she disposes of it at a place where no one passes by; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Harita: Yā pana bhikkhunī uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā... harite chaḍḍeyya vā chaḍḍāpeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 9. Throwing Waste (Crop): Should any bhikkhunī throw feces/urine/trash on living crops... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she disposes of it after having looked; if she disposes of it at the edge of the field; if she disposes of it after asking and getting permission from the owners; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Naccagīta: Yā pana bhikkhunī naccaṃ vā gītaṃ vā vāditaṃ vā dassanāya gaccheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 10. Dancing/Singing: Should any bhikkhunī go to see dancing, singing, or music... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she sees it or hears it while remaining in the monastery; if the dancing, singing, or music comes to the place where the nun is standing, sitting, or lying down; if she sees it or hears it while walking in the opposite direction; if she goes there because there is something to be done and she then sees it or hears it; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Rattandhakāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī rattandhakāre appadīpe bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekena ekā santiṭṭheyya vā sallapeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 11. Standing in Dark (Monk): Should any bhikkhunī stand or talk with a monk alone in the dark... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she has a companion who understands; if she is not seeking privacy; if she stands or talks thinking of something else; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Paṭicchanna: Yā pana bhikkhunī paṭicchanne okāse bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekena ekā santiṭṭheyya vā sallapeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 12. Secluded Place (Monk): Should any bhikkhunī stand or talk with a monk alone in a concealed place... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she has a companion who understands; if she is not seeking privacy; if she stands or talks thinking of something else; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Ajjhokāsa: Yā pana bhikkhunī ajjhokāse bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekena ekā santiṭṭheyya vā sallapeyya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 13. Open Air (Monk): Should any bhikkhunī stand or talk with a monk alone in the open air... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she has a companion who understands; if she is not seeking privacy; if she stands or talks thinking of something else; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Rathikā: Yā pana bhikkhunī rathikāya vā byūhe vā siṅghāṭake vā bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekena ekā santiṭṭheyya vā sallapeyya vā... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 14. On a Road (Monk): Should any bhikkhunī stand or talk with a monk alone on a road or cul-de-sac... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she has a companion who understands; if she is not seeking privacy; if she stands or talks thinking of something else; if she does not want to misbehave; if she dismisses her companion nun when there is something to be doneif she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Kula-upagamana: Yā pana bhikkhunī kulasūpagatā kulesu... asāmike anāpucchā nikkhameyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 15. Leaving Before Master: Should any bhikkhunī leave a family home without asking the owner, after entering... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she departs after informing someone; if the seat is not movable; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Departs without informing the owners: if, without informing a person who understands in that family, she goes beyond the roof cover of that house, she commits an offense entailing confession. If it is out in the open and she goes beyond the vicinity of the seat, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Kula-nikkhamana: Yā pana bhikkhunī kulasūpagatā kulesu... asāmike anāpucchā vikāle nikkhameyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 16. Leaving at Night: Should any bhikkhunī leave a family home at the wrong time (night) without asking... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she sits down or lies down after asking permission; if a dedicated seat is permanently ready for her; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: A seat: a place for sitting cross-legged is what is meant

rule_pali: Kula-sayana: Yā pana bhikkhunī kulasūpagatā kulesu... asāmike anāpucchā āsane nisīdeyya vā seyyaṃ vā kappeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 17. Sleeping in Family House: Should any bhikkhunī enter a family house and sit or lie down without asking the owner... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she first asks permission, and then, after putting out bedding or having it put out, sits down or lies down on it; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Bedding: even a spread of leaves

rule_pali: Anokāsa: Yā pana bhikkhunī... akkataññū aññāya vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 18. Misunderstanding: Should any bhikkhunī teach the Dhamma without analyzing the meaning/text... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Abhisapanā: Yā pana bhikkhunī attānaṃ vā paraṃ vā nirayena vā... abhisapeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 19. Cursing: Should any bhikkhunī curse herself or others with hell or darkness... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she is aiming at something beneficial; if she is aiming at giving a teaching; if she is aiming at giving an instruction; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences. If she curses someone who is not fully ordained, she commits an offense of wrong conduct

rule_pali: Rodana: Yā pana bhikkhunī attānaṃ vadhitvā vadhitvā rodeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 20. Weeping: Should any bhikkhunī weep and beat herself... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she cries, but does not beat herself, because of loss of relatives, loss of property, or loss of health; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: If she cries after repeatedly beating herself, she commits an offense entailing confession. If she beats herself, but does not cry, she commits an offense of wrong conduct. If she cries, but does not beat herself, she commits an offense of wrong conduct

rule_pali: Naggā: Yā pana bhikkhunī naggā nahāyeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 21. Bathing Naked: Should any bhikkhunī bathe naked... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If her robes have been stolen or lost; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Udakasāṭikā: Yā pana bhikkhunī udakasāṭikaṃ kārāpayamānā... pamāṇātikkantaṃ kārāpeyya... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 22. Bathing Cloth Size: Should any bhikkhunī make a bathing cloth larger than the prescribed size... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she makes it the right size; if she makes it smaller than the right size; if she gets one made by someone else that exceeds the right size and she cuts it down before using it; if she makes a canopy, a floor cover, a cloth screen, a mattress, or a pillow; if she is insane; if she is the first offender

rule_pali: Cīvarasibbana: Yā pana bhikkhunī cīvaraṃ asibbāpetvā vā... pārupitvā gāmaṃ paviseyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 23. Unsewn Robe: Should any bhikkhunī wear a robe that is not sewn... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If there is an obstacle; if she searches for someone to sew, but does not find anyone; if she is doing it, but she takes longer than four or five days; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Robe: one of the six kinds of robes. If she thinks, “I’ll neither sew it nor make any effort to have someone else sew it,” then by the mere fact of abandoning her duty, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Saṅghāṭi: Yā pana bhikkhunī pañcāhikaṃ saṅghāṭicāraṃ na dhāreyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 24. Sanghati Check: Should any bhikkhunī fail to check her outer robe (sanghati) for 5 days... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she wears or suns the five robes on the fifth day; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Does not move her robes for more than five days: if she does not wear or sun her five robes on the fifth day, then, when the fifth day has passed, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Cīvarasaṅkamanīya: Yā pana bhikkhunī cīvarasaṅkamanīyaṃ dhāreyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 25. Borrowing Robe: Should any bhikkhunī wear a robe belonging to another without permission... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If the robe has been given to her; if she wears it after asking permission; if her own robe has been stolen; if her own robe has been lost; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: A robe taken on loan: if she wears any of the five robes belonging to a fully ordained nun, and it has not been given to her, nor has she asked permission to use it, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Gaṇalābhantarāya: Yā pana bhikkhunī gaṇassa lābhaṃ antarāyaṃ kareyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 26. Blocking a Group: Should any bhikkhunī put an obstacle in the way of a group receiving robes... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she can show a benefit in obstructing them; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Creates an obstacle: if she creates an obstacle with the thought, “What can be done so that these people don’t give robe-cloth?”, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Cīvaravibhaṅga: Yā pana bhikkhunī dhammikāya cīvaravibhaṅgāya cīvaraṃ paṭibāheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 27. Blocking Ration: Should any bhikkhunī block the legal distribution of robe-cloth... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she blocks it after demonstrating a benefit; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: A legitimate distribution of robe-cloth:it is distributed by a unanimous Sangha of nuns. Blocks: if she blocks it with the thought, “What can be done so that this robe-cloth isn’t distributed?”, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Samaṇacīvara: Yā pana bhikkhunī samaṇassa vā paribbājakassa vā... cīvaraṃ dadeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 28. Giving Robe to Monk: Should any bhikkhunī give a robe to a monk/wanderer (with her own hands)... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she gives one to her mother or father; if she lends one out; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Dubbalacīvara: Yā pana bhikkhunī dubbalacīvarapaccāsāya cīvarakālasamayaṃ atikkāmeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 29. Weak Robe Time: Should any bhikkhunī let the robe season pass expecting a stronger robe... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she can show a benefit in hindering it; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: An uncertain expectation of robe-cloth: they have said, “If we’re able, then we’ll give, then we’ll act.” Lets the robe season expire: for one who has not participated in the robe-making ceremony, if she goes beyond the last day of the rainy season, she commits an offense entailing confession. For one who has participated in the robe-making ceremony, if she goes beyond the day on which the robe season ends, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Kathinuddhāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī dhammikena kathinuddhārena kathinaṃ paṭibāheyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 30. Preventing Robe Settling: Should any bhikkhunī prevent the legal settling of robe distribution... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she can show a benefit in blocking it; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Monks, I allow you to end the robe season
formulas: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. If the Sangha is ready, it should end the robe season. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The Sangha ends the robe season. Any monk who approves of ending the robe season should remain silent. Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up. The Sangha has made an end of the robe season. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Ekamañca: Dve pana bhikkhuniyo ekamañce tuvaṭṭeyyuṃ, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 31. Sleeping Two (Bed): Should two bhikkhunīs share one bed... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, when one is lying down, the other sits down; if both sit down together; if they are insane; if they are the first offenders
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Ekattharaṇa: Dve pana bhikkhuniyo ekattharaṇā tuvaṭṭeyyuṃ, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 32. Sleeping Two (Cover): Should two bhikkhunīs share one cover/blanket... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If they make a partition and then lie down; if they are insane; if they are the first offenders
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Vihesā: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā sañcicca aphāsuṃ kareyya... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 33. Intentionally Annoying: Should any bhikkhunī intentionally cause distress to another... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, after asking permission and not desiring to make her ill at ease, she walks back and forth in front of her, or she stands, sits down, or lies down in front of her, or she recites, has others recite, or rehearses in front of her; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Makes ill at ease: if, without asking permission, but thinking, “In this way she will be ill at ease,” she walks back and forth in front of her, or she stands, sits down, or lies down in front of her, or she recites, has others recite, or rehearses in front of her, she commits an offense entailing confession

rule_pali: Dukkhita: Yā pana bhikkhunī dukkhitaṃ sahajīvaniṃ na upaṭṭhāpeyya na upaṭṭhāpāpeyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 34. Family Issues: Should any bhikkhunī hide the family problems of a student... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If there is an obstacle; if she searches but does not find a nurse; if she is sick; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Applicable to Bhikkhu as dukkata offences

rule_pali: Uyyojana: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā upassayaṃ datvā... kupitā anattamanā nikaḍḍheyya... pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 35. Evicting: Should any bhikkhunī give a lodging to another and then angrily evict her... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she throws out, or has thrown out, one who is shameless; if she throws out, or has thrown out, a requisite belonging to that person; if she throws out, or has thrown out, one who is insane; if she throws out, or has thrown out, a requisite belonging to that person; if she throws out, or has thrown out, one who is quarrelsome and argumentative, and who creates legal issues in the Sangha; if she throws out, or has thrown out, a requisite belonging to that person; if she throws out, or has thrown out, a pupil or student who is not conducting herself properly; if she throws out, or has thrown out, a requisite belonging to that person; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Throws out: if she takes hold of her in a room and throws her out to the entryway, she commits an offense entailing confession. If she takes hold of her in the entryway and throws her outside, she commits an offense entailing confession. If she throws out one of her requisites, or she has it thrown out, she commits an offense of wrong conduct. If she throws out one who is not fully ordained, or she has her thrown out, from a dwelling place with or without a door, she commits an offense of wrong conduct. If she throws out one of her requisites from that place, or she has it thrown out, she commits an offense of wrong conduct

rule_pali: Sansaṭṭhā: Yā pana bhikkhunī saṃsaṭṭhā vihareyya gahapatinā vā gahapatiputtena vā, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 36. Moving w/ Husband: Should any bhikkhunī associate closely with a householder or son... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she has not been pressed; if she stops; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Socializing: she socializes with improper bodily and verbal actions
formulas: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so is socializing with householders and their offspring. And she keeps on doing it. If the Sangha is ready, it should press her to make her stop. This is the motion. Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen. The nun so-and-so is socializing with householders and their offspring. And she keeps on doing it. The Sangha presses her to make her stop. Any nun who approves of pressing nun so-and-so to make her stop should remain silent. Any nun who doesn’t approve should speak up. For the second time I speak on this matter … For the third time I speak on this matter The Sangha has pressed nun so-and-so to stop. The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus

rule_pali: Antoraṭṭha: Yā pana bhikkhunī antoraṭṭhe cārikaṃ careyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 37. Charikā (Journey): Should any bhikkhunī go on a journey (charikā) during the Rains Retreat... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If she travels with a group; if she travels where it is safe and free from danger; if there is an emergency; if she is insane; if she is the first offender
notes: Risky: a place has been seen along that road where criminals are camping, eating, standing, sitting, or lying down. Dangerous: criminals have been seen along that road, injuring, robbing, or beating people

rule_pali: Antoraṭṭhacārikā: Yā pana bhikkhunī antoraṭṭhaṃ cārikaṃ na careyya, pācittiyaṃ.
rule_english: 38. Post-Rains Journey: Should any bhikkhunī fail to go on a journey after the Rains... it is to be confessed.
