rule_english: 130. Army Battlefield: Should a bhikkhunī... go to a battlefield... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: In staying longer than three nights if they are not consecutive, or in staying longer than three consecutive nights: if one is ill or caring for someone else who is ill; if the army is surrounded by opposing forces; if one is being constrained; or if there are other dangers
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: army in active duty 2 Effort: stay two or three (consecutive) nights with the army
notes: This rule does not apply to the housing where military officers live with their families, whether on base or off

rule_pali: Surāpāna: Surāmerayapāne pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 131. Alcohol: The drinking of fermented/distilled liquors is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, having gone on business, one sees the army; if, standing within a monastery, one watches an army fighting or holding practice maneuvers nearby; if an army comes to where one happens to be; if one meets an army coming from the opposite direction; or if there are dangers
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: army in active duty 2 Effort: go to a battlefield, a roll call, the troops in battle formation, or to see a review of the (battle) units,
notes: Using the Great Standards, we may say that any show the armed forces put on for the public—parades, air shows, etc.—would also be offense here

rule_pali: Aṅgulipatodaka: Aṅgulipatodake pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 132. Tickling: Tickling with the fingers is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he drinks that which is not strong drink though it comes to be the colour of strong drink, the smell of strong drink, the taste of strong drink; if eat dishes to which alcoholic beverages, such as wine, are added for flavoring before they are cooked;. if he drinks a distilled liquor that is not strong drink; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: any alcoholic beverages 2 Effort: Consume it, even as little as the tip of a blade of grass
notes: Alcohol is criticized for it destroys one’s sense of shame, weakens one’s discernment, and can put one into a stupor, so it seems reasonable to extend this rule to other intoxicants, narcotics, and hallucinogens with these effects as well. Coffee, tea, tobacco, and betel do not have this effect, though

rule_pali: Hasadhammā: Udake hasadhamme pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 133. Water Play: Playing in the water is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, not desiring laughter, he rubs (him) if there is something to be done; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu. any unordained person, grounds for a dukkaṭa. 2) Effort: One touches any part of his body with any part of one’s own body 3) Intention: for fun
notes: If a bhikkhu massaging another bhikkhu’s tired back commits no offense if he inadvertently happens to touch a spot where the other bhikkhu is ticklish

rule_pali: Anādariya: Anādariye pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 134. Disrespect: Disrespect is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, not desiring laughter, plunging into the water if there is something to be done, or if, going to the other side, he immerses or draws out or swims; if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One jumps up or down, splashes, or swims 2) Object: in water deep enough to immerse one’s ankle 3) Intention: for fun
notes: Swimming for fitness or exercise is not discussed in any of the texts

rule_pali: Bhiṁsāpanā: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniṁ bhiṁsāpeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 135. Frightening: Should any bhikkhunī attempt to frighten another bhikkhunī, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, being admonished, one states simply that one was taught differently by one’s teachers.; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: Having been admonished by a fellow bhikkhu who cites a rule formulated in the Vinaya is Paccitiya; or for sake of being “self-effacing, scrupulous, inspiring; for lessening (defilement) or arousing energy” that are not formulated is wrong doing if one shows disrespect 2) Object: for the bhikkhu or for the rule
notes: Wise policy would be to avoid showing disrespect for another person, regardless of the situation. if one expresses disrespect behind his or her back, it would count as offense here

rule_pali: Joti: Yā pana bhikkhunī... jotiṁ samādaheyya vā samādahāpeyya vā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 136. Fire: Should any bhikkhunī... light a fire... (except for a cause), it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, not desirous of frightening, he arranges a form or a sound or a smell or a taste or a touch, or points out the dangers of thieves or of beasts of prey or ghost; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Intention: One wants to frighten the other person. 2 Effort: One arranges a frightening sight, sound, smell, taste, or tactile sensation or one describes dangers from ghosts, robbers, or wild animals. 3 Object: The other person is a bhikkhu. Anyone who is not a bhikkhu is grounds for a dukkaṭa
notes: “Result” is not a factor here. If the three factors are fulfilled, one commits the offense regardless of whether the other person is actually frightened

rule_pali: Bindu: Yā pana bhikkhunī... cīvaraṁ paribhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 137. Marking Robe: Should any bhikkhunī use a new robe without marking it... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he is ill; if he warms himself at one made by another; if he warms himself over raked-out embers; if at a lamp, in a fire-room, in a bath-room; if there is a sufficient reason for it; if there are dangers; if he is mad; if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: One is not ill. 2) Effort: One lights a fire or gets someone else to light one 3) Intention: for the purpose of warming oneself
notes: Solar or electric heating systems, which do not use flames, would not be included here
useful_texts: Fire disadvantages AN5.219, fire hall Cv 5 14.1

rule_pali: Vikappana: Yā pana bhikkhunī... cīvaraṁ vā... paribhuñjeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 138. Shared Robe: Should any bhikkhunī make use of a robe/bowl stored under shared ownership (without permission)... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it is at a right time; if he bathes at (intervals of) the half-month o more than half a month; if he bathes going to the further bank; if he is in nothing but bordering districts; if there are accidents; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Effort: Bathing more frequently than once a fortnight when residing in the middle Ganges Valley, except on certain occasions
notes: According to Mv 5 13 there is nowhere in the world outside of the middle Ganges Valley where this rule applies

rule_pali: Upanandha: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā pattaṁ vā cīvaraṁ vā... apanidheyya vā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 139. Hiding Requisites: Should any bhikkhunī hide the bowl, robe, etc. of another bhikkhunī... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, having taken, he makes use of it; if what is allowable becomes destroyed; if what made the appearance allowable becomes worn away; if what was not made allowable becomes sewn together with what was made allowable; if there is a patch; if there is a braiding; if there is a binding hem; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object:a new robe; 2 Effort: one makes use of it without first marking it
notes: A bhikkhu should wear robes only that have been marked with an identifying mark. This doesn't include sitting cloths, handkerchiefs, or shoulder bags. The Commentary details and prohibitions have no basis in the Canon or the Great Standards, they are not binding

rule_pali: Tiracchāna: Yā pana bhikkhunī sañcicca tiracchānagataṁ pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 140. Killing Animal: Should any bhikkhunī intentionally deprive an animal of life, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he gives it, or if putting his trust in him, if the shared ownership has been rescinded then he makes use of it; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer. for legitimately taking an item on trust are as follows (Mv 8 19.1): 1) The other person is a friend. 2) He/she is an intimate. 3) He/she has spoken of the matter. 4) He/she is still alive. 5) One knows that he/she will be pleased at one’s taking it
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: any one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, measuring at least four by eight fingerbreadths, that one has placed under shared ownership; 2 Effort: one uses the cloth without the shared ownership’s being rescinded
notes: Cloth that has not been made into a finished robe, rains-bathing cloths being kept outside of the rainy season, and skin-eruption covering cloths being kept when they are not needed, may all be placed under shared ownership for any length of time. The three basic robes, miscellaneous requisites, handkerchiefs, and the sitting cloth may not
formulas: “I place this robe-cloth under shared ownership with you (plural)” or “with so-and-so.” To rescinde ownership the second owner to say: “Use what is mine, give it away, or do as you like with it.”
useful_texts: Shred ownershipBu Np 1. Mv 8 20.2, 8 21.1. On trust Mv 5 13.13, Mv 8 31.2-3, Mv 8 19.1, Bu Pj 2

rule_pali: Sappāṇaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṁ sappāṇakaṁ udakaṁ paribhuñjeyya... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 141. Using Water: Should any bhikkhunī use water knowing it contains living beings... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he is not desiring fun; if he puts in order what is badly arranged; if he puts it in order, thinking, ‘I will give it back, having given dhamma-talk’; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Any of the requisites mentioned in the rule, belonging to a bhikkhu. 2 Effort: One hides the article or has it hidden. 3 Intention: One is doing it as a game
notes: Any requisite not mentioned in the rule but belonging to a bhikkhu is grounds for a dukkaṭa, as is any requisite belonging to a person who is not a bhikkhu

rule_pali: Ukkoṭana: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ yathādhammaṁ nihatādhikaraṇaṁ punakammāya ukkoṭeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 142. Reopening: Should any bhikkhunī reopen a legal issue that she knows was settled properly, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it is unintentional; if (he is) not thinking; if he does not know; if he is not meaning death; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a living animal. 2) Perception: One perceives it to be a living animal. 3) Intention: One knowingly, consciously, deliberately, and purposefully wants to cause its death. 4) Effort: whatever one does with the purpose of causing it to die. 5) Result: It dies as a result of one’s action
notes: Smallest extreme to which this rule extends is a bed bug egg. Even the desire to kill an animal to “put it out of its misery” fulfills the factor of intention all the same. no room for kappiya-vohāra there is a dukkaṭa for the first effort that touches the animal’s body; another dukkaṭa if the animal experiences pain because of one’s effort; and the full offense if, as a result, it dies

rule_pali: Duṭṭhulla: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā jānaṃ duṭṭhullaṁ āpattiṁ paṭicchādeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 143. Concealing: Should any bhikkhunī conceal another bhikkhunī's serious offense... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he makes use of it not knowing that it contains living things, knowing that it does not contain living things, knowing that they will not die from this use; if he is mad, if he is the first wrongdoer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Water containing living creatures. 2 Perception: One knows that they are there 3 Effort: all cases of using water containing living beings that are not covered by Pc 20
notes: Non-offense clauses here make no exception for a bhikkhu who uses water containing living beings either unthinkingly or unintentionally. Do not include the act of getting other people to use such water under this rule. Result is not a factor here

rule_pali: Theyyasattha: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ theyyasatthena saddhiṁ... ekaddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 144. Thieves: Should any bhikkhunī... travel together with a caravan of thieves... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he opens it up knowingly, thinking: ‘The (formal) act was carried out according to what is not the rule, or by an incomplete congregation, or against one who is not suitable for a (formal) act’; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: an issue that has been dealt with properly. 2) Perception: One knows that it was dealt with properly, either because one was directly involved or one has been told of the matter. 3) Effort: One says—in the presence of another bhikkhu—that it was dealt with improperly
notes: An issue (adhikaraṇa) is a matter that, must be dealt with formally in a prescribed manner. 1) dispute-issues (vivādādhikaraṇa) concerning Dhamma and Vinaya (see Sg 10), Community declare which side is right and which wrong; 2) accusation-issues (anuvādādhikaraṇa) concerning offenses (see Sg 8 & 9; Ay 1 & 2), Community judge them true or false; 3) offense-issues (āpattādhikaraṇa), the commission of offenses and their penalties (confession, penance, or expulsion from the Community); 4) duty-issues (kiccādhikaraṇa)—Community transactions, such ordination and holding the Pāṭimokkha recitation
useful_texts: Procedures are discussed under Pc 79 & 80, the Adhikaraṇa-samatha rules, and in BMC2, Chapters 12-22

rule_pali: Purisayātrā: Yā pana bhikkhunī purisena saddhiṁ saṁvidhāya ekaddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjeyya... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 145. Travel with Man: Should any bhikkhunī... travel together with a man, even for the interval between one village and the next, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If the bhikkhu and thieves happen to travel together without having made an arrangement; if the thieves propose an arrangement, but the bhikkhu does not give his verbal assent; if the bhikkhu leaves not as specified in the arrangement; or if there are dangers; if he is mad
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a caravan of thieves. 2) Perception: One knows that it is a caravan of thieves—either from knowing on one’s own, from having been told by one of the thieves, or from having been told by others. 3) Effort: (a) Having made an arrangement together with the caravan to travel together, (b) one actually travels together with them as arranged (c) from one village to another
notes: Thieves are who committed a theft, is on its way to commit a theft, is planning to evade a tax, or is planning to cheat the government in one way or another. Any expressed agreement to go together would fulfill this factor, regardless of whether the time frame is explicitly stated

rule_pali: Ariṭṭha: Yā pana bhikkhunī evaṁvādī assa... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 146. Evil View: Should any bhikkhunī hold an evil view... (refusing to give it up), it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he is not admonished; if he gives it up; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: Simply holding such a view is not enough to bring a bhikkhu under the purview of this rule, but if he asserts it to others, the Vibhaṅga states that other bhikkhus have the duty of reprimanding him up to three times in the manner described in the rule. If, having learned of his assertion, they do not reprimand him, they each incur a dukkaṭa, for if he goes unreprimanded, he may continue with his assertions as he likes without incurring a penalty. A Community preparing to impose this rule on a stubborn bhikkhu should also be prepared to impose a suspension transaction on him immediately in case he refuses to respond to the formal rebuke
notes: If, after being reprimanded, he relinquishes his view, he incurs no penalty. But if he doesn’t, he incurs a dukkaṭa. He should then be taken into the midst of the Community to be admonished and rebuked as described under Sg 10, the only difference here being that the penalty is a dukkaṭa in each of the preliminary stages, and a pācittiya after the third formal rebuke. (The formula for the rebuke is given in Appendix VIII BMC 1) If a bhikkhu penalized under this rule persists in asserting his evil view, he is subject to an act of suspension, under which he is not allowed to commune or affiliate with bhikkhus in any Community until he sees the error of his ways and relinquishes his view (see BMC2, Chapter 20
formulas: Venerable sirs, may the Community listen to me. An evil viewpoint of this sort has arisen in Bhikkhu (name): “As I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One, those acts the Blessed One says are obstructive, when engaged in are not genuine obstructions.” He does not relinquish that view. If the Community is ready, it should rebuke Bhikkhu (name) for the sake of relinquishing that view. This is the motion. 3 times Bhikkhu (name) has been rebuked by the Community for the sake of relinquishing that view. This is agreeable to the Community, therefore it is silent. Thus do I hold it. Apendix XIII BMC 1
useful_texts: Obstructions in MN 54, AN5.76, AN6.86. AN6.87, SN6.10. BU Pc 69-70

rule_pali: Ukkhitta: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ tathāvādiniṁ bhikkhuniṁ... sambhuñjeyya vā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 147. Associating: Should any bhikkhunī knowingly eat/stay with a bhikkhunī who talks that way (and hasn't given up the view)... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he knows, “He is not suspended”; if he knows, “He was suspended, he is restored”; if he knows, “He has given up that view”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bhikkhu who has been suspended by a Community transaction and has not yet been restored. 2) Perception: One knows that he has been suspended and has not yet been restored 3) Effort: One communes with him, affiliates with him, or lies down in the same dwelling with him
notes: According to Cv.I.25-35, a bhikkhu may be suspended for: 1 He refuses to relinquish an evil view, as in the preceding rule; 2 he refuses to see an offense; or 3 he refuses to make amends for an offense
formulas: Suṇātu me bhante saṅgho. Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno evarūpaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ uppannaṁ, “Tathāhaṁ bhagavatā dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi, yathā ye’me antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā, te paṭisevato nālaṁ antarāyāyā” ti. So taṁ diṭṭhiṁ nappaṭinissajjati. Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho Itthannāmaṁ bhikkhuṁ samanubhāseyya tassā diṭṭhiyā paṭinissaggāya. Esā ñatti

rule_pali: Kaṇṭaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ tathānāsitaṁ sāmaṇeraṁ... upalāpeyya vā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 148. Expelled Novice: Should any bhikkhunī... support/associate with a novice (who holds wrong views)... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he knows, “He is not expelled”; if he knows, “He has given up that view”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a novice who has been expelled and has not relinquished his evil view. 2) Perception: One perceives that he has been expelled and has not relinquished his evil view—either from knowing on one’s own, from having been told by him (§), or from having been told by others. 3) Effort: One befriends him, receives services from him, communes with him, or lies down in the same dwelling with him
notes: A novice comes to think that there is nothing wrong with any novice’s having sexual intercourse or breaking any of his other precepts. This form of expulsion lasts as long as he has yet to relinquish his view. If and when he does relinquish it, he is to be reinstated. As under the preceding rule, the Vibhaṅga states explicitly that the first not offence clause holds regardless of whether one’s perception is correct, and the same principle would seem to apply to the second one as well
formulas: Similar to BU-PC68 but for novice instead of bhikkhu
useful_texts: BU-PC68-69. Mv 1 57-60 expelling a novice BMC2, Chapter 14

rule_pali: Sahadhammika: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhunīhi sahadhammikaṁ vuccamānā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 149. Refusing Admonition: Should any bhikkhunī... say "I will not train in this rule until I have asked another"... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: To avoid an offense in situations like this is to say that one will learn about the rule and train in line with it. As the non-offense clauses to Pc 54 make clear, though, if one has been admonished with any interpretation of a rule that differs from one’s teachers’, one may avoid an offense simply by stating that one’s teachers taught differently
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: One has been admonished by a fellow bhikkhu who cites a rule formulated in the Vinaya. 2) Intention: One does not want to train oneself in line with the rule. 3) Effort: As a ploy to excuse oneself, one says something to the effect that one will not train in line with the rule
notes: This rule deals with cases where a bhikkhu tries to excuse himself from following any of the training rules without showing out-and-out disrespect for the rule or the person admonishing him. (If he showed out-and-out disrespect, the case would come under Pc 54

rule_pali: Vilekhana: Yā pana bhikkhunī pātimokkhe uddissamāne evaṁ vadeyya: "Kiṁ panimehi khuddānukhuddakehi...", pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 150. Criticizing Rules: Should any bhikkhunī... say "Why are these lesser and minor rules recited...?", it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, without intending to criticize the discipline, one suggests to another person that he/she master the suttas, the gāthās (verses), or the Abhidhamma first, before mastering the discipline
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Effort: One criticizes the discipline in the presence 2) Object: of another bhikkhu 3) Intention: with the intent of disparaging it
notes: Pācittiya for criticizing the discipline in the presence of a bhikkhu; and a dukkaṭa for criticizing any other Dhamma in his presence, or criticizing either the discipline or any other Dhamma in the presence of an unordained. The bhikkhu may be subject to an act of censure or banishment, depending on the seriousness of the case

rule_pali: Moha: Yā pana bhikkhunī pātimokkhe uddissamāne evaṁ vadeyya: "Idāneva kho ahaṁ ayye jānāmi...", pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 151. Deceived: Should any bhikkhunī... say "I just now understood that this rule is in the Pātimokkha"... (when she actually knew), it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he is not heard in detail; if he is heard in detail (but) less than two or three times; if he does not desire to deceive; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a rule in the Pāṭimokkha. 2) Intention: One wants to deceive the bhikkhus into believing that one is ignorant of the rule one has broken. 3) Effort: One has heard the Pāṭimokkha in full for at least three times, yet one persists in saying half-truths to feign ignorance after the bhikkhus have enacted a Community transaction exposing one’s deceit. (Out-and-out lies would come under Pc 1.)
notes: This rule covers the use of a half-truth to feign ignorance of the rules at any time. No exceptions for bhikkhus whose native language is not Pali. Nevertheless, as the Pāṭimokkha is available in a number of translations, the grace period in which one is expected to be ignorant—three recitations covers at least a month to a month and a half—is not too short a time for a new bhikkhu to read and remember the rules in translation. If the transaction exposing one’s deceit has been properly carried out, then regardless of whether one perceives it as valid, one incurs a pācittiya for trying to deceive the bhikkhus any further. If it has been improperly carried out, one incurs a dukkaṭa for trying to deceive them further,
formulas: Suṇātu me bhante saṅgho. Ayaṁ Itthannāmo bhikkhu pāṭimokkhe uddissamāne na sādhukaṁ aṭṭhikatvā manasikaroti. Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno mohaṁ āropeyya. Esā ñatti. Āropito saṅghena Itthannāmassa bhikkhuno moho. Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī. Evam-etaṁ dhārayāmi. Venerable sirs, may the Community listen to me. This Bhikkhu (name), when the Pāṭimokkha is being recited, does not pay attention, properly taking it to heart. If the Community is ready, it should expose Bhikkhu (name)’s deceit. This is the motion. Bhikkhu (name)’s deceit has been exposed by the Community. This is agreeable to the Community, therefore it is silent. Thus do I hold it

rule_pali: Pahāra: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā kupitā anattamanā pahāraṁ dadeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 152. Hitting: Should any bhikkhunī, angered and displeased, give a blow to (another) bhikkhunī, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, being in some difficulty, he gives a blow desiring freedom; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu is grounds for the full offense here; anyone unordained, grounds for a dukkaṭa. 2) Effort: One gives him a blow: with one’s own body, with something attached to the body or something that can be “thrown” 3) Intention: out of anger
notes: “Result” is not a factor here. Whether the other person is hurt—or how badly he/she is hurt—does not affect the offense. In self-defense even if anger or displeasure arises in one’s mind in cases like this, there is no penalty

rule_pali: Talasattika: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā kupitā anattamanā talasattikaṁ uggireyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 153. Raising Palm: Should any bhikkhunī... raise the palm of her hand against (another) bhikkhunī, it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If being in some difficulty, he raises the palm of the hand desiring freedom; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu is grounds for the full offense here; anyone unordained, grounds for a dukkaṭa. 2) Effort: Raising the palm of one’s hand or raising any part of one’s body or anything attached to the body (a stick, a rock, a gun, a bow and arrow) in a threatening manner. 3) Intention: out of anger
notes: Sub-commentary also notes that if an animal, for example, is making a mess and a bhikkhu raises his hand against it, this would be included under desiring freedom—i.e., from the mess—and so would not be an offense

rule_pali: Amūlaka: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniṁ amūlakena saṅghādisesena anuddhaṃseyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 154. False Charge: Should any bhikkhunī charge a bhikkhunī with a Saṅghādisesa offense without basis... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If one makes the accusation—or gets someone else to make it—when one thinks it to be true, even if the other bhikkhu is actually not guilty of the offense; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu. 2) Perception: One has not seen, heard, or suspected him of committing the offense one is charging him with. 3) Effort: One accuses him in his presence—or gets someone else to accuse him in his presence—of having committed a saṅghādisesa offense
notes: If one makes an unfounded charge accusing another bhikkhu of a defect in conduct or a defect in view, the penalty is a dukkaṭa

rule_pali: Kukkucca: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhuniyā sañcicca kukkuccaṁ upadaheyya... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 155. Anxiety: Should any bhikkhunī intentionally cause anxiety to a bhikkhunī... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, not desiring to arouse remorse, he speaks, saying: ‘Surely you, (though) under twenty years of age, are ordained … surely you sit in a private place together with a woman; come now, find out (about it), do not let there come to be remorse for you afterwards;’ if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: another bhikkhu, an unordained person grounds for a dukkaṭa. 2) Effort: One mentions that he might have broken a rule. 3) Result: One provokes anxiety in him. 4) Intention: One’s motive is simply to cause him anxiety even if just for a moment
notes: The factor of effort can be fulfilled by any statement one might make to another bhikkhu insinuating that he may have broken a rule, even if the action mentioned is not actually an offense

rule_pali: Upassuti: Yā pana bhikkhunī bhikkhunīnaṁ bhaṇḍanajātānaṁ... upassutiṁ tiṭṭheyya... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 156. Eavesdropping: Should any bhikkhunī... go to eavesdrop on bhikkhunīs... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If having heard these he goes away, thinking: ‘I will desist, I will refrain, I will be calm, I will set myself free’; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: other bhikkhus who are involved in an argument over an issue. unordained person grounds for dukkata 2) Effort: One stands eavesdropping on them, 3) Intention: with the purpose of using what they say against them, either as part of a formal accusation (charging, interrogating, counter-charging, or counter-interrogating them) or simply to make them feel abashed
notes: Regardless of whether the two parties in the dispute are confronting each other or one party is talking in private. even a single bhikkhu, involved in an argument with an unordained person, would be grounds for the full offense. People who are not involved in an argument are not grounds for an offense. At present, surreptitiously reading another person’s mail would seem to fulfill this factor as well

rule_pali: Kammapaṭibāhana: Yā pana bhikkhunī dhammikānaṁ kammānaṁ chandaṁ datvā... khiyyana-dhammaṁ āpajjeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 157. Protest: Should any bhikkhunī... having given consent to formal acts... later complain... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he criticises, knowing, “The (formal) act was carried out according to what is not the rule or by an incomplete assembly or against one not suitable for a (formal) act”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a valid transaction to which one has given one’s consent. 2) Perception: One perceives it as valid. Valid transaction that one perceives as valid: pācittiya; an invalid transaction that one perceives to be valid and a transaction that one is doubtful about, regardless of its actual validity: dukkaṭas; a transaction that one perceives to be invalid, regardless of its actual validity: grounds for no offense. 3) Effort: One complains about it
notes: An invalid protest would be one made by someone who is not a bhikkhu, by a bhikkhu who is insane, possessed by a spirit, outside the territory, or suspended from the Community, or by the bhikkhu against whom the act is being carried out
useful_texts: BU-PC63, 80. Sangha acts Cv 4, Mv 9 2.4, complete assembly Mv 2 5.2,6.1,12.7; consent by proxy Mv 2 23.1-2; protest Mv 9 3.5-6, 4.7-8; community vs another Mv 9 2.3. BMC2, Chapter 12

rule_pali: Chanda: Yā pana bhikkhunī saṅghe vinicchayakathāya vattamānāya... chandaṁ adatvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkameyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 158. Leaving: Should any bhikkhunī... rise from her seat and leave (the assembly) without having given consent... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he goes away, thinking: “There will come to be quarrel or dispute or strife or contention for the Order”; if he goes away, thinking: “There will come to be schism in the Order or dissension in the Order”; if he goes away, thinking: “He will carry out the (formal) act according to what is not rule, or by an incomplete congregation, or against one not suitable for a (formal) act”9; if, being ill, he goes away; if he goes away because there is something to be done for one who is ill; if he goes away to relieve himself;* if anxious not to find fault with the (formal) act, he goes away, thinking: “I will come back again”; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a Community transaction that has been started but has yet to be finished, and is being carried out in a valid manner. 2) Perception: One perceives it as being carried out in a valid manner. Valid transaction that one perceives as valid: pācittiya; an invalid transaction that one perceives to be valid and a transaction that one is doubtful about, regardless of its actual validity: dukkaṭas; a transaction that one perceives to be invalid, regardless of its actual validity: grounds for no offense. 3) Intention: One wants to invalidate the transaction or to keep the group from carrying it out. 4) Effort: Without having first given one’s consent, one goes beyond hatthapāsa (1.25 m.) from the bhikkhus sitting in the meeting
notes: A bhikkhu who has committed this offense would, under Cv.IX.3, be subject to having his Pāṭimokkha canceled. This would provide the Community with the opportunity to look into his attitude and to take further disciplinary actions if it sees fit

rule_pali: Dabba: Yā pana bhikkhunī samaggena saṅghena cīvaraṁ datvā... khiyyana-dhammaṁ āpajjeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 159. Agreeing: Should any bhikkhunī... give a robe... and later complain... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he criticises, saying: ‘What is the use of giving to one acting by nature from desire, from hatred, from confusion, from fear? For having received it, he will ruin it, he will not look after it properly if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: One has acted as part of a united Community that has given robe-cloth to a bhikkhu who has been chosen, through a prior Community transaction, to be a Community official. 2) Effort: One complains afterward that the Community acted out of favoritism
notes: Community acting as a whole may take inexpensive articles (lahubhaṇḍa) belonging to it and turn them over to individual bhikkhus or novices with a simple declaration (apalokana)
useful_texts: BU-PC13 and 63; Community’s gains Cv 6 15.2, BMC2, Chapter 7 and 18

rule_pali: Pariṇāmana: Yā pana bhikkhunī jānaṃ saṅghikaṁ lābhaṃ pariṇataṁ puggalassa pariṇāmeyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 160. Diverting: Should any bhikkhunī knowingly divert a gain dedicated to the Community to an individual... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he himself being asked, ‘Where do we give?’ says, ‘Give wherever your gift could be used or could be mended or should be for a long time or when for you the mind is peaceful;’ if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1 Object: Any requisite that donors have indicated by word or gesture that they intend to give to a Community. 2 Perception: One perceives that the donors have allocated the requisite for a Community. 3 Effort: One tries to persuade them that they should give it to another individual instead. 4 Result: he obtains the article from the donors
notes: Divert items allocated for a Community to another individual full offense. To divert items allocated for one Community of bhikkhus to another Community or to a shrine (cetiya) entails a dukkaṭa. Or for a shrine to a Community, to an individual, or to another shrine; and for diverting items allocated for an individual to a Community, to a shrine, or to another individual

rule_pali: Antepura: Yā pana bhikkhunī rājānaṁ khattiyaṁ... indakhīlaṁ atikkameyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 161. King's Chamber: Should any bhikkhunī cross the threshold of an anointed king's bedchamber... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If, within a monastery or a dwelling, one picks up a valuable or what is considered a valuable—or if one has it picked up—with the thought, “Whoever this belongs to will come for it.”; no matter where it is found if one takes it on trust, borrows it, or perceives it as having been thrown away
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a valuable or anything considered a valuable that one finds left behind, except in a monastery or a dwelling that one is visiting. 2) Perception: One does not perceive it as discarded. 3) Intention: One wants to keep it in safe keeping for the owner. 4) Effort: One picks it up or has someone else pick it up
notes: The general purpose of this rule is to prevent a bhikkhu from picking up misplaced valuables belonging to other people, for as the origin story shows, there are dangers inherent in such an act even when done with the best intentions. if a bhikkhu has picked up a fallen valuable in the monastery he should take note of its features and ask about them to whom claim it

rule_pali: Ratana: Yā pana bhikkhunī ratanaṁ vā ratanasammataṁ vā... uggaṇheyya vā... pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 162. Valuables: Should any bhikkhunī pick up a valuable... (except in a monastery/house for safekeeping), it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If is for fastener, a fire-starter, a belt fastener, an ointment box, a stick for applying ointment, an adze handle, and a water wiper. This list was apparently intended simply to be illustrative
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a needle box made of bone, ivory, or horn. 2) Effort: One obtains it after making it or having it made 3) Intention: for one’s own use
notes: This rule, was putting a halt to the sort of fad that can occur among bhikkhus when certain requisites become fashionable to the point of inconveniencing donors. One must break the box before confessing the offense

rule_pali: Vikālagāma: Yā pana bhikkhunī santaṁ bhikkhuniṁ anāpucchā vikāle gāmaṁ paviseyya, pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 163. Village Time: Should any bhikkhunī enter a village at the wrong time (after noon) without taking leave... it is to be confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he makes it to the (proper) measure; if he makes it less than the (proper) measure; if, having acquired what was made for another, (but) exceeding the (proper) measure, having cut it down, he makes use of it; if he is mad, if he is the first wrongdoer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bed or bench whose legs, measuring from the lower side of the frame to the floor, are longer than eight sugata fingerbreadths (16.7 cm.) 2) Effort: One obtains it after making it or having it made 3) Intention: for one’s own use
notes: The purpose of this rule is to prevent bhikkhus from making and using furnishings that are high and imposing. One must cut the bed/bench down to the proper size before confessing the offense. If one obtains a tall bed/bench made by another—not at one’s instigation—then using it entails a dukkaṭa 8 sugata fingerbreadths would be equal to 16.7 cm
formulas: Here we take the sugata span to equal 25 cm.,

rule_pali: Sūcighara: Yā pana bhikkhunī aṭṭhimayaṁ vā... sūcigharaṁ kārāpeyya, bhedanakaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 164. Needle Box: Should any bhikkhunī have a needle box made of bone, ivory, or horn, it is to be broken and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If it is for a binding, for a girdle, for a shoulder-strap, for a bag for carrying the bowl in, for a water-strainer; if he is making a squatting-mat; if, having acquired what was made for another, having torn it off, he makes use of it; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a bed or bench stuffed with cotton down. 2) Effort: One obtains it after making it or having it made 3) Intention: for one’s own use
notes: The purpose of all this is to keep bhikkhus from using furnishings that are extravagant and ostentatious, according to present day standard. one must tear off the upholstery before confessing the offense

rule_pali: Mañcapīṭha: Yā pana bhikkhunī mañcaṁ vā pīṭhaṁ vā kārāpayamānā... chedanakaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 165. Bed Height: Should any bhikkhunī have a bed or bench made with legs exceeding 8 fingerbreadths, it is to be cut down and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he makes it to the (proper) measure; if he makes it less than the (proper) measure; if having acquired what was made for another (but) exceeding the (proper) measure, having cut it down, he makes use of it; if he makes a canopy or a ground-covering or a screen-wall or a mattress or a squatting-mat; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: a skin-eruption covering cloth larger than the standard measure. 2) Effort: One obtains it after making it or having it made 3) Intention: for one’s own use
notes: Skin-eruption covering cloth to protect their robes when they are suffering from boils, running sores, rashes, or “thick scab” diseases. Here we take the sugata span to equal 25 cm., which would put the standard measurement for the skin-eruption covering cloth at 1 meter by 50
formulas: Here we take the sugata span to equal 25 cm.,
useful_texts: Mv 8 17 allows bhikkhus to use a skin-eruption covering cloth

rule_pali: Tūlonaddha: Yā pana bhikkhunī mañcaṁ vā pīṭhaṁ vā tūlonaddhaṁ kārāpeyya, uddālanakaṁ pācittiyaṁ.
rule_english: 166. Cotton Bedding: Should any bhikkhunī have a bed or bench made stuffed with cotton, it is to be torn open and confessed.
no_offense_factors: If he makes it to the (proper) measure; if he makes it less than the (proper) measure; if having acquired what was made for another (but) exceeding the (proper) measure, having cut it down, he makes use of it; if he makes a canopy or a ground-covering or a screen-wall or a mattress or a squatting-mat; if he is mad, if he is the first wrong-doer
offense_factors_bmc: 1) Object: any robe larger than the standard measure. 2) Effort: One obtains it after making it or having it made 3) Intention: for one’s own use
notes: Taking the sugata span to be 25 cm. would put the size of the Buddha’s robes at 2.25 m. by 1.50 m.—much larger than the lower robes used at present, but much smaller than present-day upper and outer robes
formulas: Here we take the sugata span to equal 25 cm.,

pali_name: Asking for Ghee, Oil, Honey, Molases, Fish, Meat, Milk, Curd
rule_pali:
1 Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā sappiṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya, paṭidesetabbaṁ tāya bhikkhuniyā: "gārayhaṁ, ayye, dhammaṁ āpajjiṁ asappāyaṁ pāṭidesanīyaṁ, taṁ paṭidesemī"ti. 2Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā telaṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

3Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā madhuṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

4Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā phāṇitaṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

5Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā macchaṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

6Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā maṁsaṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

7Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā khīraṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya … pe … taṁ paṭidesemīti.

8Yā pana bhikkhunī agilānā dadhiṁ viññāpetvā bhuñjeyya, paṭidesetabbaṁ tāya bhikkhuniyā: "gārayhaṁ, ayye, dhammaṁ āpajjiṁ asappāyaṁ pāṭidesanīyaṁ, taṁ paṭidesemī"ti.
rule_english: 1. Should any bhikkhunī, not being ill, ask for ghee and consume it, she is to acknowledge it: "Lady, I have committed a blameworthy, unsuitable act that ought to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it."  2—8. Should any bhikkhunī, not being ill, ask for oil… honey… sugar/molasses… fish… meat… milk… curds and consume it, she is to acknowledge it: "Lady, I have committed a blameworthy, unsuitable act that ought to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it."

rule_pali: Uppannuppannānaṃ adhikaraṇānaṃ samathāya vūpasamāya sammukhāvinayo dātabbo. sativinayo dātabbo. amūḷhavinayo dātabbo. paṭiññāya kāretabbaṃ. yebhuyyasikā. tassapāpiyasikā. tiṇavatthārakoti
rule_english: For the calming, for the stilling of whichever legal issues that have arisen: the removal through the presence [of the bhikkhu] is to be given, the removal [of the accusation] through remembrance is to be given, the removal through [no longer being] insane is to be given, he is to be made to do [the offence-procedure] through admitting [the offence], the [decision of the] majority, [the decision making it] worse for him, [settling] in the manner of spreading grass
notes: Same as Bhikkhus Sekhiya
